title: Cat. 126 John Grove, 1895
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 1261895Way: 93  
Levy: 145  
Transfer lithograph, drawn on thin, transparent transfer paper  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, center right  
One state; image size: 207 × 154 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 6  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 32, 61, 309  
Posthumous edition: 25 impressions printed by Goulding on 20 October 1903  
Posthumous watermarks: 24, 50–56, 169, 200, 219, 220, 241, 315, 323  
Stone: erased in 1903  
Whistler-Way Letters: 145; app. II.4  
Selected Literature: Way (1912), p. 116  
Lifetime Exhibitions: Chicago 1900a (no. 86)

John Grove was the landlord of the Royal Lion Hotel, where Whistler and his wife stayed during their visit to Lyme Regis, Dorset. The artist drew the innkeeper’s portrait as he sat, facing forward, with a drink in his hand. A few days earlier Whistler had selected much the same pose for his lithographic portrait of the elderly George Govier, The Master Smith (cat. 120). When he finished the portrait of Grove, Whistler departed from his usual practice and inscribed the sitter’s name and the name of the hotel at the right of the image.

John Grove was transferred to stone and proved on 5 October 1895 (app. II.4). By October 10 Whistler had received the first proofs of this and three other lithographs. He was disappointed with the images, as he had been with the proofs of his first seven Lyme Regis lithographs (cat. 119, cat. 120, cat. 121, cat. 122, cat. 123, cat. 124, and cat. 125). He wrote immediately to the Ways, instructing them to print no more impressions of the last four lithographs and to refrain from showing the images to anyone (letter 145). He concluded his brief letter by saying: “The Landlord is bad doubtless my fault entirely.”

Chicago: AIC, cream laid paper (250 × 182 mm), signed; MWC, ivory laid paper (247 × 192 mm), signed. London: BM, cream laid paper (280 × 225 mm). Washington: LC, ivory wove proofing paper (284 × 224 mm), signed; NGA, ivory laid paper (247 × 192 mm), signed.

Remarks: Other impressions are found in Cincinnati, CMA; Cleveland, CMA; and New York, MMA.  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">The Blacksmith (cat. 127) and The Brothers (cat. 128) were also included in this group. The fourth lithograph was probably The Old Smith’s Story (cat. 129).

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 126, only state. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Crown Family in honor of James N. Wood, 2004.625.

</section>
